Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A transit authority superviO35r has just entered the cabin for an immediate and unannounced performance audit.
Story: I sat in the subway operator’s seat, hands steady on the controls, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. The group chat was blowing up—my teammates were arguing again, and the project deadline was slipping through our fingers. As a mentee, I knew I was supposed to reach out to my mentor right away, let her know about the conflict and ask for guidance. But just as I considered sending a quick message, the cabin door slid open. My supervisor stepped in, clipboard in hand, eyes sharp. “Performance audit,” he announced, settling in behind me. My heart pounded. I was expected to follow every protocol perfectly, no distractions, no mistakes. But my mind kept drifting to the chaos in my group, the responsibility to communicate honestly with my mentor. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention at the exact same moment.
